San Bernardino County


Which are the best, worst states to retire to? (Hint: Neither is California, by these rankings)


The statistical geeks at WalletHub, Bankrate and Kiplinger’s recently took their respective shots at measuring how each state compares in terms of livability factors for your retirement years: from costs to culture to that critical aging issue, healthcare.Let’s politely say the conclusions varied.So who’s correct? Who do you trust? Retirement choices are no small matter.Let me take a literal middle ground by...

Emilio Ramirez, of the Greater Riverside Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, supports the Cadiz scheme to mine water from the ancient aquifer below the eastern Mojave Desert. The chamber was presumably influenced by Cadiz’ promise of “6,000 jobs” to be created by the project (the adjectives “skilled” and “highly paid” were not used by Cadiz).

San Bernardino County


Which are the best, worst states to retire to? (Hint: Neither is California, by these rankings)


The statistical geeks at WalletHub, Bankrate and Kiplinger’s recently took their respective shots at measuring how each state compares in terms of livability factors for your retirement years: from costs to culture to that critical aging issue, healthcare.Let’s politely say the conclusions varied.So who’s correct? NewsCrime + Public Safety


Parking in front of your own driveway can cost you a ticket


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Cars in a line at night under red street light. Cars parked at night. generic
By Jim Radcliffe | jradcliffe@scng.com | Orange County Register

PUBLISHED: July 14, 2018 at 6:01 am | UPDATED: July 14, 2018 at 9:48 pm

Q. Honk, can I park on the street and block my own driveway? In my area, I get a lot of apartment and condo visitors parking on the street in front of my house. I put up with it, but it would be nice if they wouldn’t do it on Thanksgiving and Christmas. Those two days really bother me, especially when it is in regard to my immediate neighbors. What your mom once told you is right on: People should be courteous and, if possible, park in front of their friends’ homes when visiting.


– Jim Fuchs, Santa Ana


A. As tempting as it is, Jim, try not to park in front of your driveway.


Cpl. Anthony Bertagna, the spokesman for Santa Ana P.D., said that under the law you cannot park blocking even your own driveway.


“However, as with all tickets, it is at the discretion of the handling officer,” the good corporal said. “Often, if it is at the owner’s residence, they do not cite and just advise them of the law.”


That law, by the way, is from the Califoirnia Vehicle Code, so it covers the entire Golden State.


Q. Honk, the sign below a freeway on-ramp traffic-control light often reads, “One car per green.” Can I take the signage literally – one car per green? Let’s say I am the only car on the ramp and I see green, but it turns red again before I can get there. Can I just continue through without stopping?


– Susan Posilovich, Irvine


A. No.


The point of those ramp meters is to even out the flow of traffic on the freeway, so Honk gets your logic.


But the law is strict: You can only go on a green, even if there was no motorist before you on the ramp for 10 minutes. And the green is so short, don’t try rolling up to it and timing it.


Just stop and wait.


“You are going to treat it like any other red light,” said Duane Graham, an officer and spokesman for the California Highway Patrol out of the agency’s Westminster station house.


Susan, you are obviously asking about this because you want to do the right thing. Plenty of motorists, though, just blow through those red lights knowing they are breaking the law.


Nabbing such cheaters probably isn’t high on most CHP officers’ lists of biggest concerns. But there is a device out there to help them get those who don’t bother stopping when the meter lights are on.


On the backsides of a few ramp meters are lights that allow officers downstream to tell if the meter light is red or green. The cops, in their black-and-whites farther down the ramp pointed toward the freeway, can eyeball the driver and the light in their rear-view mirrors. When a violation occurs, they just drop behind the offenders and pull them over.


That device’s name? A tattletale light.


Honkin’ fact: When a 2-year-old boy died in a hot car in Sacramento over the weekend, it was the 57th time in California a child has died in a hot car since 1990, according to kidsandccars.org, an advocacy group. Each year, the organization says, an average of 37 children die in hot cars in the United States.


To ask Honk questions, reach him at honk@ocregister.com. He only answers those that are published. To see Honk online: ocregister.com/tag/honk.

Show Caption
of

Expand


Four years after its attendance numbers hit an all-time low, San Bernardino County Museum in 2016-17 continues to make gains in visitors, officials reported earlier this month.


Attendance at the main museum in Redlands slid to 38,000 in 2014 – down from 109,000 in 2001. In the past fiscal year, which ended June 30, attendance at the main museum rose to 63,351, a 66 percent increase from 2014.


Though attendance has yet to return to 2001 levels, museum and county officials are celebrating the turnaround.


“We’re totally excited that more people are coming because ultimately that’s what we want to do,” said museum director Melissa Russo. “We really want to connect residents to the culture and history and environment of the county.”


In 2014, a consulting firm recommended 29 changes at the museum, following revelations about problems in leadership.


Since then, the museum brought on Russo, successfully earned a 10-year accreditation, and has been steadily growing attendance numbers. The museum, based in Redlands with sites in Rancho Cucamonga, Colton, Yucaipa and more, saw a 14 percent increase in visitors to all sites in 2016-17.


At the Victor Valley Museum branch in Apple Valley alone, attendance grew 48 percent in the past year, from 5,523 to 8,222.


Russo said the museum’s success stems from increasing the rate of new exhibits and programs to keep visitors coming back. An increase in school field trips – up to 17,000 from about 13,500 students in the past year at the main museum alone – also helped.


Meanwhile, museum curators are broadening exhibits.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

The “Minerals Rock! Unearthing the Human Element” exhibit, which opened July 5 in Redlands, isn’t just about geology, it includes biology and chemistry, and discusses mining in the area, cultural history, the different colors of minerals and how different cultures used them for dying textiles or making jewelry.


“We’re trying to make all of our exhibits very multi-disciplinary so that it tells a fuller story,” Russo said. “So a rock is not just a rock, it’s connected to everything else; it’s part of a story, it’s part of our history, it’s part of the industry of this area.”


“Mechanized Magic: 40 Years of Garner Holt Productions in San Bernardino County,” which runs through Nov. 25 in Redlands, is another crowd-pleaser, she said.


The show follows the rise of the animatronics giant, which was founded in 1977 in Holt’s parents’ San Bernardino garage, offering a look into science, technology, engineering, art and mathematics fields with hands-on opportunities.

  * Riverside County officials try to capture, treat wild burro shot with an arrow
  * ‘Brady Bunch’ home in Studio City for sale

  * Fewer searchers now looking for hiker in Joshua Tree National Park

In Apple Valley, attendance gains are thanks at least in part to the CuriousCITY exhibit for children under 5, which opened in August, Russo said.


The early-learning interactive play space encourages kids to use their imagination with a city theme, offering post office and store structures, and costumes.


Next up, the museum plans a citrus exhibit tying in agriculture and history. It’s set to open in May, with a tongue-in-cheek working title of “Pulp Culture.”


“We are seeing impressive measureable results in attracting visitors to our county museums,” Board of Supervisors Chairman Robert Lovingood said in a news release from the museum. “I think changes we’ve made in recent years are paying off, and I’m optimistic the trend will continue.”


Attendance, Russo said, is just one data point, “but I think it’s one of the most important ones that illustrates whether or not we’re of interest to the community. That’s our mission. If people aren’t coming, we might as well close our doors.”


The museum aims to exceed 100,000 visitors at the main site in Redlands by 2022.


San Bernardino County Museum


Hours: 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through Sundays


Where: 2024 Orange Tree Lane, Redlands


Admission: Up to $10, depending on age, military service, etc.


Information: 909-798-8608 or sbcounty.gov/museum


Branch sites: Agua Mansa Pioneer Cemetery, Colton; Rains House, Rancho Cucamonga; Victor Valley Museum, Apple Valley; and Yucaipa Adobe. Hours vary. Admission is up to $5. Temporarily closed sites include Asistencia in Redlands and Yorba and Slaughter Families Adobe in Chino.

Redlands man who was stabbed is charged with indecent exposure

* By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise
PUBLISHED: July 17, 2018 at 8:08 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 11:01 pm

The man who Redlands police say exposed himself to a woman at a city park before she stabbed him in the back has been charged with indecent exposure.


Ryan Edward Brewer, 28, was arrested about 4 p.m. Tuesday, July 17, at his apartment in Redlands, police spokesman Carl Baker said. The San Bernardino County District Attorney’s Office also charged Brewer on Tuesday. His bail was set at $100,000.


Cynthia Christine Molina, 51, was arrested July 11 on suspicion of assault with a deadly weapon in what initially was believed to be a random attack. But Brewer withheld information that he argued with and exposed himself to Molina at Jennie Davis Park at Redlands Boulevard and New York Street, police said.


Molina on Monday pleaded not guilty. She is due back in court July 24 for a hearing.

Judge rules against 3,600-house Harmony development proposed for Highland

* Wendy Rea, founder of the Greenspot Residents Association, stands at a section of the proposed Harmony Development site in Highland on Friday, July 6, 2018. In late June a judge in two cases ruled against the proposed 3,600-house Harmony Development saying the city improperly defined the project and failed to properly analyze or mitigate downstream flooding impacts, and more. (Photo by Stan Lim, The Press-Enterprise/SCNG)
By Jennifer Iyer | jiyer@scng.com | Redlands Daily Facts

PUBLISHED: July 6, 2018 at 6:34 pm | UPDATED: July 9, 2018 at 2:13 pm

A judge has ruled against Highland’s proposed 3,600-house Harmony development, partially siding with environmental and community groups that opposed the massive project in two related lawsuits.


The suits, filed in September 2016, challenged the city’s approval of the project due to what they called an “inadequate” environmental report.


Superior Court Judge Donald Alvarez found the report failed to analyze the entire scope of the project in leaving out a needed bridge over Mill Creek. Impacts on flooding, and to water and wildlife habitat were also not fully considered, he said.


  * Wendy Rea, founder of the Greenspot Residents Association, walks through a section of the proposed Harmony Development site in Highland on Friday, July 6, 2018. In late June a judge in two cases ruled against the 3,600-house project saying the city improperly defined the project and failed to properly analyze or mitigate downstream flooding impacts, and more.(Photo by Stan Lim, The Press-Enterprise/SCNG)


  * Wendy Rea, founder of the Greenspot Residents Association, walks through a section of the proposed Harmony Development site in Highland on Friday, July 6, 2018. In late June a judge in two cases ruled against the 3,600-house project for Highland saying the city improperly defined the project and failed to properly analyze or mitigate downstream flooding impacts, and more.(Photo by Stan Lim, The Press-Enterprise/SCNG)

  * Sound
    The gallery will resume inseconds

  * Wendy Rea, founder of the Greenspot Residents Association, stands at a section of the proposed Harmony Development site in Highland on Friday, July 6, 2018. In late June a judge in two cases ruled against the proposed 3,600-house Harmony Development saying the city improperly defined the project and failed to properly analyze or mitigate downstream flooding impacts, and more. (Photo by Stan Lim, The Press-Enterprise/SCNG)

* Show Caption
of

Expand


Petitioners in both suits sought to throw out the city’s certification of the report and approvals of the project. City officials and the developer now are determining what they’ll do next.


Larry Mainez, the city’s community development director, said Thursday the city had just received word about the ruling and was still figuring out how to proceed. The rulings, filed in late June, had been mailed to the parties, and were received Thursday.


“We received the ruling, and our team is reviewing it,” said Randall Lewis, executive vice president of developer Lewis Group of Companies. “We will be deciding what the next steps are.”


This map from the Harmony Specific Plan environmental impact report shows the Highland housing project, outlined in red, in relation to nearby cities and roads.

In fall 2016, the Highland City Council consented to putting the Harmony master planned community before voters in November 2018, reversing course on its approval of the project after opponents gathered enough signatures to force a recall or seek voter input. The council had approved the project in August 2016.


At that point Mayor Larry McCallon had said placing the matter on the ballot likely would not impact the construction timeline.


“It was never envisioned construction would start for the next three, four or five years, anyway,” he had said.


McCallon did not return multiple phone calls by late afternoon Friday.


“The next step will be determining what the remedy the Judge will issue since the Petition was granted in part and denied in part,” said Aruna Prabhala, an attorney with petitioner Center for Biological Diversity in an email. “…The Judge found the environmental impact report was inadequate on a number of issues which will likely have to be addressed before the project moves forward.”


When the remedy will be issued is uncertain as it hinges on the completion of several procedural steps, she said.


A similar ruling was recently handed down for what would be one of the nation’s largest warehouse facilities proposed for eastern Moreno Valley. On June 14 Riverside County Superior Court Judge Sharon J. Waters tossed out the World Logistics Center project’s environmental report, setting aside that city’s approvals, and barring it from issuing any permits.


The Greenspot lawsuit


On June 27 Alvarez filed a ruling on a suit bought by the Center, the Greenspot Residents Association and the San Bernardino Valley Audobon Society. The lawsuit contended the environmental report excluded the construction of the Newport Avenue bridge over Mill Creek as part of the project. The claim said the proposed bridge would need to include room for wildlife to pass under it due to the location of wildlife corridors at the boundaries of the project site. Alvarez ruled that the bridge should be considered part of the project.


That suit also suggested the report improperly concluded the project’s greenhouse gas emissions would be less than significant. The judge denied this, saying evidence supported the methodology used for compliance with state emission reduction rules.


The third piece of the suit claimed the environmental report failed to address the amount of fill needed to raise a portion of the site out of the 100-year floodplain, and the downstream impacts of the grading needed at the project’s southern boundary.


Alvarez ruled the exact plan to raise homes out of the flood plain was less than certain at the time the city had approved the report as the Federal Emergency Management Agency had not yet reviewed and approved detailed hydrological analyses for the zone.


The report’s discussion of water drainage from the foothills northeast of the site was also lacking according to the judge. At the time the report was approved runoff rates had not yet been determined. Determinations regarding impacts and mitigation measures require completed studies, Alvarez ruled.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

“(My neighbors) are ecstatic,” said Wendy Rea, founder of the Greenspot Residents Association, and a longtime resident of Mentone and Redlands. “I think many people in the community had lost hope.”


“Our concerns,” she added, “were with understanding the heritage of flood history of this area and the risks were just simply being ignored,” she said.


The ruling, she said, has restored their faith.


Another lawsuit


Alvarez filed a 90-page ruling June 26 in a related suit brought by the Sierra Club, Crafton Hills Open Space Conservancy, Tri-County Conservation League and Friends of Riverside Hills.


Related Articles

  * San Bernardino secures $20 million for affordable housing community Arrowhead Grove
  * Redlands sells citrus grove for $1.9 million to protect it from development

Alvarez granted a similar point about the city failing to analyze the whole of the project by excluding the bridge, and said there is no substantial evidence supporting the city’s conclusions regarding project alternatives, and impacts on alluvial fan sage scrub habitat, water resources, wastewater and energy conservation.


He found evidence supports the city’s conclusions on impacts to a different sage scrub habitat, wildlife corridors, earthquake risk, aesthetics, wildfire hazards, hazardous materials, cultural resources and greenhouse gas emissions.


“It’s a great next step,” Rea of the Highland rulings. “We’ve let the system carry it forward and now we’ll see what their next move is.”

Business


Which are the best, worst states to retire to? (Hint: Neither is California, by these rankings)


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)

  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)

* By Jonathan Lansner | jlansner@scng.com | Orange County Register
PUBLISHED: July 19, 2018 at 4:44 am | UPDATED: July 19, 2018 at 4:45 am

The statistical geeks at WalletHub, Bankrate and Kiplinger’s recently took their respective shots at measuring how each state compares in terms of livability factors for your retirement years: from costs to culture to that critical aging issue, healthcare.


Let’s politely say the conclusions varied.


So who’s correct? Who do you trust? Retirement choices are no small matter.


Let me take a literal middle ground by considering their collective wisdom. As a public service, my trusty spreadsheet helped me combine this trio of retirement location rankings to give a better picture of the varying strengths vs. weaknesses of the states.


I reassembled their published ranking data — overall scores, subindex grades and related data — into three evenly weighted metrics: costs (buying power); character (culture and climate); and care (healthcare and healthiness). What did I learn?


Florida is the place to retire, statistically speaking to my composite index. It ranked No. 1 for costs and character. But if you don’t care for humidity, and enjoy winter’s chill, No. 2 was South Dakota, which enjoyed No. 4 grades for costs and care.


Third-ranked was New Hampshire (No. 4 for character; 10th-best for care), then Virginia: (ninth-best for character) and Hawaii (No. 40 for costs but No. 1 for care!)


Conversely, don’t think about Louisiana for your golden years, according to my math. It ranked last in my reassembled scorecard. Why? No. 49 for character and No. 50 for care.


Next worst score was Arkansas (No. 47 for character), then came Kentucky (No. 47 for care); New Mexico (No. 46 for character) and Illinois (No. 41 for care).


What about California? By my math, the Golden State ranked a middle-of-the-pack 26th for one’s golden years. California’s seventh-worst ranking for costs was improved by a No. 16 grade for character and No. 18 for care.


Here is how the 50 states ranked as retirement options in order of my overall scoring then broken down by ranking for cost, character and care quality.

2    South Dakota   4    20        1

Business


Which are the best, worst states to retire to? (Hint: Neither is California, by these rankings)


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)

* By Jonathan Lansner | jlansner@scng.com | Orange County Register
PUBLISHED: July 19, 2018 at 4:44 am | UPDATED: July 19, 2018 at 4:45 am

The statistical geeks at WalletHub, Bankrate and Kiplinger’s recently took their respective shots at measuring how each state compares in terms of livability factors for your retirement years: from costs to culture to that critical aging issue, healthcare.


Let’s politely say the conclusions varied.


So who’s correct? Who do you trust? Retirement choices are no small matter.


Let me take a literal middle ground by considering their collective wisdom. As a public service, my trusty spreadsheet helped me combine this trio of retirement location rankings to give a better picture of the varying strengths vs. weaknesses of the states.


I reassembled their published ranking data — overall scores, subindex grades and related data — into three evenly weighted metrics: costs (buying power); character (culture and climate); and care (healthcare and healthiness). What did I learn?


Florida is the place to retire, statistically speaking to my composite index. It ranked No. 1 for costs and character. But if you don’t care for humidity, and enjoy winter’s chill, No. 2 was South Dakota, which enjoyed No. 4 grades for costs and care.


Third-ranked was New Hampshire (No. 4 for character; 10th-best for care), then Virginia: (ninth-best for character) and Hawaii (No. 40 for costs but No. 1 for care!)


Conversely, don’t think about Louisiana for your golden years, according to my math. It ranked last in my reassembled scorecard. Why? No. 49 for character and No. 50 for care.


Next worst score was Arkansas (No. 47 for character), then came Kentucky (No. 47 for care); New Mexico (No. 46 for character) and Illinois (No. 41 for care).


What about California? By my math, the Golden State ranked a middle-of-the-pack 26th for one’s golden years. California’s seventh-worst ranking for costs was improved by a No. 16 grade for character and No. 18 for care.


Here is how the 50 states ranked as retirement options in order of my overall scoring then broken down by ranking for cost, character and care quality.

Rank State          Cost Character Care
1    Florida        1    1         2   
2    South Dakota   4    20        1   
3    New Hampshire  22   4         3   
4    Virginia       18   9         6   
5    Hawaii         40   8         12  
6    Utah           7    33        4   
7    Montana        18   18        12  
8    Massachusetts  34   4         29  
9    Iowa           37   10        8   
10   Vermont        50   2         38  
11   Colorado       20   28        9   
12   Idaho          21   25        5   
13   Delaware       12   26        14  
14   Maine          48   3         21

20   Connecticut    42   6         41

22   Nebraska       33   27        18

24   Missouri       7    31        11  
25   Wisconsin      46   14        28  
26   California     44   16        38  
27   North Dakota   37   37        10  
28   Alabama        11   44        22  
29   Texas          3    40        18  
30   Tennessee      1    42        16  
31   Oregon         32   19        35  
32   Ohio           28   15        25

34   Rhode Island   43   13        45  
35   New Jersey     47   11        46

37   West Virginia  27   23        41  
38   Nevada         5    41        32

50   Louisiana      22   49        48

Riverside County officials try to capture, treat wild burro shot with an arrow


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)

* A feral burro was wounded over the weekend and Riverside County Animal Services wants to capture and treat it. Photo courtesy Riverside County Department of Animal Services.
By City News Service |

PUBLISHED: July 19, 2018 at 12:36 am | UPDATED: July 19, 2018 at 12:36 am

MORENO VALLEY — A wild burro was shot with an arrow, but eluded rescue efforts Wednesday.


Riverside County Department of Animal Services spokesman John Welsh said the feral donkey was wounded over the weekend, and a concerned resident posted images of the animal to social media, catching the attention of authorities.


Welsh described the attack on the burro as a “terrible act of cruelty” that left the animal in need of veterinary care.


The burro was spotted in the Reche Canyon area, in the vicinity of the Black Stallion Ranch, north of Moreno Valley, and animal control officers went to the location Wednesday afternoon, Welsh said.


“We shot it with two tranquilizer darts, but efforts to capture the wild burro were unsuccessful,” Welsh said. “The darts should have been enough, and we are uncertain why they were not effective.


“It could have been a result of the animal being worked up earlier, prior to our arrival,” he said.


The arrow was no longer protruding from the creature when the darts were injected, but the wound was still visible, according to Welsh


Officers will return to the area Thursday morning to have another go at corralling the burro.


Welsh said the nonprofit DonkeyLand rescue organization has been alerted and will be enlisted to assist.


Officials asked anyone with information regarding who might have injured the donkey to contact the Department of Animal Services at (951) 358-7387.


Herds of wild burros populate the Pigeon Pass and Reche Canyon areas between Moreno Valley and Colton. Riverside County Ordinance No. 934 makes it unlawful to feed, pet or otherwise draw the donkeys toward roadsides and other locations where they might be hurt — or wander into traffic and cause accidents.

Riverside County officials try to capture, treat wild burro shot with an arrow


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)

* A feral burro was wounded over the weekend and Riverside County Animal Services wants to capture and treat it. Photo courtesy Riverside County Department of Animal Services.
By City News Service |

PUBLISHED: July 19, 2018 at 12:36 am | UPDATED: July 19, 2018 at 12:36 am

MORENO VALLEY — A wild burro was shot with an arrow, but eluded rescue efforts Wednesday.


Riverside County Department of Animal Services spokesman John Welsh said the feral donkey was wounded over the weekend, and a concerned resident posted images of the animal to social media, catching the attention of authorities.


Welsh described the attack on the burro as a “terrible act of cruelty” that left the animal in need of veterinary care.


The burro was spotted in the Reche Canyon area, in the vicinity of the Black Stallion Ranch, north of Moreno Valley, and animal control officers went to the location Wednesday afternoon, Welsh said.


“We shot it with two tranquilizer darts, but efforts to capture the wild burro were unsuccessful,” Welsh said. “The darts should have been enough, and we are uncertain why they were not effective.


“It could have been a result of the animal being worked up earlier, prior to our arrival,” he said.


The arrow was no longer protruding from the creature when the darts were injected, but the wound was still visible, according to Welsh


Officers will return to the area Thursday morning to have another go at corralling the burro.


Welsh said the nonprofit DonkeyLand rescue organization has been alerted and will be enlisted to assist.


Officials asked anyone with information regarding who might have injured the donkey to contact the Department of Animal Services at (951) 358-7387.


Herds of wild burros populate the Pigeon Pass and Reche Canyon areas between Moreno Valley and Colton. Riverside County Ordinance No. 934 makes it unlawful to feed, pet or otherwise draw the donkeys toward roadsides and other locations where they might be hurt — or wander into traffic and cause accidents.

* Ernesto Santos, 49, of Ontario, was arrested Wednesday, July 18, on suspicion of child molestation. (Courtesy of Ontario Police Department)
By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 8:34 pm | UPDATED: July 19, 2018 at 12:46 am

A 49-year-old Ontario resident was arrested Wednesday, July 18, on suspicion of child molestation.


Ernesto Santos is believed to have molested a family member numerous times, an Ontario police news release said. He was arrested in the 1000 block of North Mountain Avenue on suspicion of lewd and lascivious acts with a child younger than 14. He is being held at West Valley Detention Center in lieu of $500,000 bail.


Investigators believe Santos may have sexually assaulted other children, the release said. They ask anyone with information to call Detective Dave Newland at 909-408-1898 or 909-986-6711, or report tips anonymously to We-Tip at 800-782-7463 or to its website at wetip.com.

Brian Rokos writes about public safety issues such as policing, criminal justice, scams, how law affects public safety, firefighting tactics and wildland fire danger. He has also covered the cities of San Bernardino, Corona, Norco, Lake Elsinore, Perris, Canyon Lake and Hemet. Before that he supervised reporters and worked as a copy editor. For some reason, he enjoys movies where the Earth is threatened with extinction.

* Ernesto Santos, 49, of Ontario, was arrested Wednesday, July 18, on suspicion of child molestation. (Courtesy of Ontario Police Department)
By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 8:34 pm | UPDATED: July 19, 2018 at 12:46 am

A 49-year-old Ontario resident was arrested Wednesday, July 18, on suspicion of child molestation.


Ernesto Santos is believed to have molested a family member numerous times, an Ontario police news release said. He was arrested in the 1000 block of North Mountain Avenue on suspicion of lewd and lascivious acts with a child younger than 14. He is being held at West Valley Detention Center in lieu of $500,000 bail.


Investigators believe Santos may have sexually assaulted other children, the release said. They ask anyone with information to call Detective Dave Newland at 909-408-1898 or 909-986-6711, or report tips anonymously to We-Tip at 800-782-7463 or to its website at wetip.com.

Fewer searchers now looking for hiker in Joshua Tree National Park

* In this Monday, July 16, 2018 photo posted on the Joshua Tree National Park Twitter page, searchers hike through Joshua Tree National Park, Calif, looking Paul Miller, 51-year-old Canadian man missing since heading out for a hike Friday morning, July 13. Trackers with dogs and others are focusing on the 49 Palms Oasis trail, located in the southern area of the vast desert park about 150 miles (241 kilometers) east of Los Angeles. (Hannah Schwalbe/National Park Service via AP)
By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 7:44 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 7:46 pm

The search for a hiker who was reported missing in Joshua Tree National Park on Friday was scaled back Wednesday, July 18, after another day of no sign of the man.


Paul Miller, 51, of Canada, was last seen by his wife about 9 a.m. Friday when he left for a hike on the 49 Palms Oasis trail. She reported him overdue about noon. His car was found in the parking lot at the trailhead.


Missing hiker in the 49 Palms Oasis area. If you have any information please call 909-383-5651. pic.twitter.com/CcHMcJiKfw


— Joshua Tree NPS (@JoshuaTreeNPS) July 14, 2018


At its height, the operation included 90 ground searchers, six K-9 teams, an ATV search team and a helicopter. Searchers will continue to look in areas with the highest probability of success, a Facebook post by the National Park Service said.


Officials ask that anyone with information on Miller’s whereabouts or who has any other helpful details call 909-383-5651.

News


Crime + Public Safety


Teen shooting victim abandoned in Yucaipa was involved in burglary, sheriff says


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)
* By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise
PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 6:00 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 7:33 pm

The 16-year-old gunshot victim who had been dropped behind a 7-Eleven in Yucaipa on Saturday by motorists who then fled had earlier attempted to burglarize the home of a 69-year-old man who owns a gun, the San Bernardino County Sheriff’s Department said.


The teenage boy, who is a Desert Hot Springs resident, and two other men had tried to break in to a home in the 33000 block of Wallace Way in Yucaipa, a news release said. The homeowner confronted the three as they tried to force their way through a backyard window. As they fled, he fired one shot, striking the teen.


The driver of the vehicle was seen placing the teen on the ground behind the 7-Eleven near Yucaipa Boulevard and 14th Street just before 6:15 p.m. and then driving off. The homeowner reported the burglary 30 minutes later but not the shooting, the release said.

Sign up for our breaking news email newsletter: When major local news happens, you will be the first to know. Subscribe here.

Tuesday, detectives found evidence at the home that the 69-year-old had fired his gun. They also found the Ford Mustang GT driven by the burglars, the release said. Detectives are trying to find the two men and a woman who were in the car and left the 16-year-old behind.


No one has been arrested and the names of those involved have not been publicly released. The District Attorney’s Office will determine whether to bring charges.


Deputies ask anyone with information about the incident to call Deputy Coillot at the Yucaipa Station, 909-918-2305. Anonymous calls can be made to the We-Tip Hotline at 800-782-7463 or the website at wetip.com.

Show Caption
of

Expand


Four years after its attendance numbers hit an all-time low, San Bernardino County Museum in 2016-17 continues to make gains in visitors, officials reported earlier this month.


Attendance at the main museum in Redlands slid to 38,000 in 2014 – down from 109,000 in 2001. In the past fiscal year, which ended June 30, attendance at the main museum rose to 63,351, a 66 percent increase from 2014.


Though attendance has yet to return to 2001 levels, museum and county officials are celebrating the turnaround.


“We’re totally excited that more people are coming because ultimately that’s what we want to do,” said museum director Melissa Russo. “We really want to connect residents to the culture and history and environment of the county.”


In 2014, a consulting firm recommended 29 changes at the museum, following revelations about problems in leadership.


Since then, the museum brought on Russo, successfully earned a 10-year accreditation, and has been steadily growing attendance numbers. The museum, based in Redlands with sites in Rancho Cucamonga, Colton, Yucaipa and more, saw a 14 percent increase in visitors to all sites in 2016-17.


At the Victor Valley Museum branch in Apple Valley alone, attendance grew 48 percent in the past year, from 5,523 to 8,222.


Russo said the museum’s success stems from increasing the rate of new exhibits and programs to keep visitors coming back. An increase in school field trips – up to 17,000 from about 13,500 students in the past year at the main museum alone – also helped.


Meanwhile, museum curators are broadening exhibits.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

The “Minerals Rock! Unearthing the Human Element” exhibit, which opened July 5 in Redlands, isn’t just about geology, it includes biology and chemistry, and discusses mining in the area, cultural history, the different colors of minerals and how different cultures used them for dying textiles or making jewelry.


“We’re trying to make all of our exhibits very multi-disciplinary so that it tells a fuller story,” Russo said. “So a rock is not just a rock, it’s connected to everything else; it’s part of a story, it’s part of our history, it’s part of the industry of this area.”


“Mechanized Magic: 40 Years of Garner Holt Productions in San Bernardino County,” which runs through Nov. 25 in Redlands, is another crowd-pleaser, she said.


The show follows the rise of the animatronics giant, which was founded in 1977 in Holt’s parents’ San Bernardino garage, offering a look into science, technology, engineering, art and mathematics fields with hands-on opportunities.

  * Fewer searchers now looking for hiker in Joshua Tree National Park

In Apple Valley, attendance gains are thanks at least in part to the CuriousCITY exhibit for children under 5, which opened in August, Russo said.


The early-learning interactive play space encourages kids to use their imagination with a city theme, offering post office and store structures, and costumes.


Next up, the museum plans a citrus exhibit tying in agriculture and history. It’s set to open in May, with a tongue-in-cheek working title of “Pulp Culture.”


“We are seeing impressive measureable results in attracting visitors to our county museums,” Board of Supervisors Chairman Robert Lovingood said in a news release from the museum. “I think changes we’ve made in recent years are paying off, and I’m optimistic the trend will continue.”


Attendance, Russo said, is just one data point, “but I think it’s one of the most important ones that illustrates whether or not we’re of interest to the community. That’s our mission. If people aren’t coming, we might as well close our doors.”


The museum aims to exceed 100,000 visitors at the main site in Redlands by 2022.


San Bernardino County Museum


Hours: 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through Sundays


Where: 2024 Orange Tree Lane, Redlands


Admission: Up to $10, depending on age, military service, etc.


Information: 909-798-8608 or sbcounty.gov/museum


Branch sites: Agua Mansa Pioneer Cemetery, Colton; Rains House, Rancho Cucamonga; Victor Valley Museum, Apple Valley; and Yucaipa Adobe. Hours vary. Admission is up to $5. Temporarily closed sites include Asistencia in Redlands and Yorba and Slaughter Families Adobe in Chino.

Show Caption
of

Expand


Four years after its attendance numbers hit an all-time low, San Bernardino County Museum in 2016-17 continues to make gains in visitors, officials reported earlier this month.


Attendance at the main museum in Redlands slid to 38,000 in 2014 – down from 109,000 in 2001. In the past fiscal year, which ended June 30, attendance at the main museum rose to 63,351, a 66 percent increase from 2014.


Though attendance has yet to return to 2001 levels, museum and county officials are celebrating the turnaround.


“We’re totally excited that more people are coming because ultimately that’s what we want to do,” said museum director Melissa Russo. “We really want to connect residents to the culture and history and environment of the county.”


In 2014, a consulting firm recommended 29 changes at the museum, following revelations about problems in leadership.


Since then, the museum brought on Russo, successfully earned a 10-year accreditation, and has been steadily growing attendance numbers. The museum, based in Redlands with sites in Rancho Cucamonga, Colton, Yucaipa and more, saw a 14 percent increase in visitors to all sites in 2016-17.


At the Victor Valley Museum branch in Apple Valley alone, attendance grew 48 percent in the past year, from 5,523 to 8,222.


Russo said the museum’s success stems from increasing the rate of new exhibits and programs to keep visitors coming back. An increase in school field trips – up to 17,000 from about 13,500 students in the past year at the main museum alone – also helped.


Meanwhile, museum curators are broadening exhibits.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

The “Minerals Rock! Unearthing the Human Element” exhibit, which opened July 5 in Redlands, isn’t just about geology, it includes biology and chemistry, and discusses mining in the area, cultural history, the different colors of minerals and how different cultures used them for dying textiles or making jewelry.


“We’re trying to make all of our exhibits very multi-disciplinary so that it tells a fuller story,” Russo said. “So a rock is not just a rock, it’s connected to everything else; it’s part of a story, it’s part of our history, it’s part of the industry of this area.”


“Mechanized Magic: 40 Years of Garner Holt Productions in San Bernardino County,” which runs through Nov. 25 in Redlands, is another crowd-pleaser, she said.


The show follows the rise of the animatronics giant, which was founded in 1977 in Holt’s parents’ San Bernardino garage, offering a look into science, technology, engineering, art and mathematics fields with hands-on opportunities.


Related Articles

  * Which are the best, worst states to retire to? (Hint: Neither is California, by these rankings)
  * Riverside County officials try to capture, treat wild burro shot with an arrow
  * ‘Brady Bunch’ home in Studio City for sale
  * Man gets 3 years in prison for making illegal drugs after his lab ignited a house fire in Wildomar
  * Fewer searchers now looking for hiker in Joshua Tree National Park

In Apple Valley, attendance gains are thanks at least in part to the CuriousCITY exhibit for children under 5, which opened in August, Russo said.


The early-learning interactive play space encourages kids to use their imagination with a city theme, offering post office and store structures, and costumes.


Next up, the museum plans a citrus exhibit tying in agriculture and history. It’s set to open in May, with a tongue-in-cheek working title of “Pulp Culture.”


“We are seeing impressive measureable results in attracting visitors to our county museums,” Board of Supervisors Chairman Robert Lovingood said in a news release from the museum. “I think changes we’ve made in recent years are paying off, and I’m optimistic the trend will continue.”


Attendance, Russo said, is just one data point, “but I think it’s one of the most important ones that illustrates whether or not we’re of interest to the community. That’s our mission. If people aren’t coming, we might as well close our doors.”


The museum aims to exceed 100,000 visitors at the main site in Redlands by 2022.


San Bernardino County Museum


Hours: 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through Sundays


Where: 2024 Orange Tree Lane, Redlands


Admission: Up to $10, depending on age, military service, etc.


Information: 909-798-8608 or sbcounty.gov/museum


Branch sites: Agua Mansa Pioneer Cemetery, Colton; Rains House, Rancho Cucamonga; Victor Valley Museum, Apple Valley; and Yucaipa Adobe. Hours vary. Admission is up to $5. Temporarily closed sites include Asistencia in Redlands and Yorba and Slaughter Families Adobe in Chino.

Local News


Redlands working on solutions to Market Night congestion


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)

* Erik Breazile, with the City of Redlands Parks Department, directs traffic as vendors arrive to set up for Market Night on State Street in downtown Redlands, CA., Thursday, June 14, 2018. (Photo by Jennifer Cappuccio Maher/Redlands Daily Facts/SCNG)
By Jennifer Iyer | jiyer@scng.com | Redlands Daily Facts

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 5:10 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 5:11 pm

The Redlands City Council on Tuesday, July 17, tabled a resolution created to alleviate some of the State Street congestion leading up to Thursday Market Nights, but the city is still working on the problem.


An increase in downtown visitors over the past few years has led to problems for State Street shops, and Market Night vendors.


“We are victims of our success downtown, and that’s what we are grappling with,” said Mayor Paul Foster.


Patrons of the brick and mortar stores have to leave parking spaces by 5:30 p.m., but were sometimes blocked by vendors setting up for the 6 p.m. event, according to complaints received by city staff.


The city changed vendor set-up time to 5:30 p.m. in May, but some vendors, especially those selling food, had problems setting up in half an hour. When many cars needed to be towed, on a recent night there were 20, vendors had to wait even longer until they got the chance to set up.


And 6 p.m. is prime selling time, farmer and vendor Bill Cunningham told the council. The proposal the council tabled had been to push back the start time to 6:30 p.m.


City staff said they would look into posting more signs to make sure patrons know they need to move their cars by 5:30 p.m., and will also talk to vendors, especially local farmers, and State Street business owners to find a solution.


The matter will be in front of the City Council again in September when they return from their August break.

Business


Southern California car wash mogul to pay $4.2 million for cheating 800 workers


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Workers finish cleaning cars at the Brea Car Wash and Detail Center at 1700 East Lambert Road in Brea on Wednesday, Feb. 14, 2018. (Photo by Paul Bersebach, Orange County Register/SCNG)
By Margot Roosevelt | mroosevelt@scng.com | Orange County Register

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 4:32 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 9:44 pm

A Southern California car wash mogul cited for cheating more than 800 workers and destroying evidence will pay $4.2 million in back wages and penalties after a two-year court battle with federal authorities.


Vahid David Delrahim, of Los Angeles, failed to pay his workers minimum wage or overtime at a dozen car washes in Orange, Los Angeles, San Bernardino and Ventura counties, according to the U.S. Department of Labor.


A consent decree approved this week by U.S. District Court Judge Fernando Olguin orders Delrahim to pay $1.9 million in back wages and another $1.9 million in damages to the workers. In addition, he is fined $400,000 in civil penalties.


“This landmark case sends a powerful message that the Department of Labor will use strong law enforcement and litigation tools to protect employees and level the playing field for law-abiding employers,” said Juan Coria, the wage and hour division’s acting regional commissioner.


According to the judgment, Delrahim ordered employees, many of them Spanish-speakers unfamiliar with U.S. labor laws, to work off the clock at the beginning of each shift and to clock out, but to remain at the car washes, when business was slow. The result: numerous hours without pay.


The court-ordered back wages cover a period from 2013 to the present. More workers and more money may be added to the case, according to the 42-page decree, as “the identity of all employees who worked [at the 12 car washes] is presently unknown.”


Delrahim is required to furnish more names, addresses and workplace records—originally requested by prosecutors in 2016—within 30 days.


As a result of the judgment, some employees will receive more than $10,000 in back wages.


Delrahim, a prominent member of Southern California’s Iranian diaspora and a cousin of President Donald Trump’s anti-trust chief, Makan Delrahim, owns more than 100 car washes and gas stations through Agoura Hills-based companies: Brea Car Wash & Detail Center (also known as Southwest Fuel Management), Goldenwest Solutions Group, and California Payroll Group.


David Delrahim

“We made a business decision to end the civil litigation,” his public relations firm said in a statement. “Our decision did not admit any wrongdoing on our part, but will enable the leaders and employees of our business to focus their time and effort on business instead of a costly civil trial.”


State and federal officials bring hundreds of wage theft claims each year against California car washes, garment contractors, caregiver facilities, restaurants and construction firms—the industries with the highest number of violations.


The Delrahim case is unusual in that few wage and hour disputes end up in court. But Delrahim hired one of the nation’s most aggressive employer law firms, Littler Mendelson, leading to two years of court battles and more than 200,000 pages in filings, documents, depositions and testimony.


Delrahim’s Los Angeles-based lawyer, Rebecca Aragon, specialized in helping “companies employing Spanish-speaking work forces” with “union avoidance” and other strategies, according to her firm biography.


The case exploded into a fight over legal ethics. Shortly after the investigation began, Delrahim and Littler were notified of the duty to preserve potential evidence. Nonetheless, text messages, email accounts and videos recording workers’ comings and goings, which prosecutors deemed likely to prove the government’s case, were destroyed.


The court sanctioned Delrahim and Littler five times for withholding documents and for coercive tactics towards employee witnesses. They were ordered to reimburse the government $23,850 in legal fees.


“The court’s decisions make clear that our laws protect workers and neither an employer nor their attorneys may interfere with their rights,” said Regional Solicitor Janet Herold.


The settlement attested to the lack of trust. It orders Delrahim not to encourage his managers “to ensure that labor costs are kept at or below a fixed percentage of the car wash’s sales.” And it appoints an “independent monitor” who can enter his car washes for a year without prior notice to inspect all payroll records and time cards.


The dozen illegally operated car washes include:

  * Brea Car Wash & Detail Center (Brea)
  * Steve’s Detailing (Newport Beach)
  * Newport Coast Car Wash (Newport Beach)
  * Placentia Car Wash (Placentia)
  * Laguna Hills Auto Spa (Laguna Hills)
  * Coast Hand Car Wash & Detail Center (Long Beach)
  * Alicia Auto Spa & Detail Center (Laguna Hills)
  * Agoura Hills Car Wash (Agoura Hills)
  * Lavaggio (Agoura Hills)
  * Las Posas Car Wash (Camarillo)
  * Redlands Auto Spa (Redlands)
  * Redlands Car Wash & Detail Center (Redlands)

Business


Southern California car wash mogul to pay $4.2 million for cheating 800 workers


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Workers finish cleaning cars at the Brea Car Wash and Detail Center at 1700 East Lambert Road in Brea on Wednesday, Feb. 14, 2018. (Photo by Paul Bersebach, Orange County Register/SCNG)
By Margot Roosevelt | mroosevelt@scng.com | Orange County Register

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 4:32 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 9:44 pm

A Southern California car wash mogul cited for cheating more than 800 workers and destroying evidence will pay $4.2 million in back wages and penalties after a two-year court battle with federal authorities.


Vahid David Delrahim, of Los Angeles, failed to pay his workers minimum wage or overtime at a dozen car washes in Orange, Los Angeles, San Bernardino and Ventura counties, according to the U.S. Department of Labor.


A consent decree approved this week by U.S. District Court Judge Fernando Olguin orders Delrahim to pay $1.9 million in back wages and another $1.9 million in damages to the workers. In addition, he is fined $400,000 in civil penalties.


“This landmark case sends a powerful message that the Department of Labor will use strong law enforcement and litigation tools to protect employees and level the playing field for law-abiding employers,” said Juan Coria, the wage and hour division’s acting regional commissioner.


According to the judgment, Delrahim ordered employees, many of them Spanish-speakers unfamiliar with U.S. labor laws, to work off the clock at the beginning of each shift and to clock out, but to remain at the car washes, when business was slow. The result: numerous hours without pay.


The court-ordered back wages cover a period from 2013 to the present. More workers and more money may be added to the case, according to the 42-page decree, as “the identity of all employees who worked [at the 12 car washes] is presently unknown.”


Delrahim is required to furnish more names, addresses and workplace records—originally requested by prosecutors in 2016—within 30 days.


As a result of the judgment, some employees will receive more than $10,000 in back wages.


Delrahim, a prominent member of Southern California’s Iranian diaspora and a cousin of President Donald Trump’s anti-trust chief, Makan Delrahim, owns more than 100 car washes and gas stations through Agoura Hills-based companies: Brea Car Wash & Detail Center (also known as Southwest Fuel Management), Goldenwest Solutions Group, and California Payroll Group.


David Delrahim

“We made a business decision to end the civil litigation,” his public relations firm said in a statement. “Our decision did not admit any wrongdoing on our part, but will enable the leaders and employees of our business to focus their time and effort on business instead of a costly civil trial.”


State and federal officials bring hundreds of wage theft claims each year against California car washes, garment contractors, caregiver facilities, restaurants and construction firms—the industries with the highest number of violations.


The Delrahim case is unusual in that few wage and hour disputes end up in court. But Delrahim hired one of the nation’s most aggressive employer law firms, Littler Mendelson, leading to two years of court battles and more than 200,000 pages in filings, documents, depositions and testimony.


Delrahim’s Los Angeles-based lawyer, Rebecca Aragon, specialized in helping “companies employing Spanish-speaking work forces” with “union avoidance” and other strategies, according to her firm biography.


The case exploded into a fight over legal ethics. Shortly after the investigation began, Delrahim and Littler were notified of the duty to preserve potential evidence. Nonetheless, text messages, email accounts and videos recording workers’ comings and goings, which prosecutors deemed likely to prove the government’s case, were destroyed.


The court sanctioned Delrahim and Littler five times for withholding documents and for coercive tactics towards employee witnesses. They were ordered to reimburse the government $23,850 in legal fees.


“The court’s decisions make clear that our laws protect workers and neither an employer nor their attorneys may interfere with their rights,” said Regional Solicitor Janet Herold.


The settlement attested to the lack of trust. It orders Delrahim not to encourage his managers “to ensure that labor costs are kept at or below a fixed percentage of the car wash’s sales.” And it appoints an “independent monitor” who can enter his car washes for a year without prior notice to inspect all payroll records and time cards.


The dozen illegally operated car washes include:

  * Brea Car Wash & Detail Center (Brea)
  * Steve’s Detailing (Newport Beach)
  * Newport Coast Car Wash (Newport Beach)
  * Placentia Car Wash (Placentia)
  * Laguna Hills Auto Spa (Laguna Hills)
  * Coast Hand Car Wash & Detail Center (Long Beach)
  * Alicia Auto Spa & Detail Center (Laguna Hills)
  * Agoura Hills Car Wash (Agoura Hills)
  * Lavaggio (Agoura Hills)
  * Las Posas Car Wash (Camarillo)
  * Redlands Auto Spa (Redlands)
  * Redlands Car Wash & Detail Center (Redlands)

News


Amid climate change and recent deaths, coalition demands worker protections from extreme heat


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* DWP crews work to restore power after weekend heat outages. (Courtesy LADWP)
By Brenda Gazzar | bgazzar@scng.com | Daily News

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 2:17 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 5:49 pm

Raudel Felix García of Fontana thought someone was playing a cruel joke on him when he was told a decade ago that his brother had died after working in the grape fields of Kern County.


Audon Felix García had arrived from Zacatecas, Mexico just days before to work in the fields as he had done every other summer, his brother said. But the 41-year-old died two days after starting work loading boxes on the company truck, he said, due to temperatures that reached 112 degrees that summer day and employer “negligence” to properly care for him.


“It was hard to believe that he was simply gone,” a highly emotional Raudel Felix García, who owns his own landscaping business, said Tuesday in a media teleconference. “I had seen Audon five days before his death. He was healthy and ready to start another harvesting season.”


Audon Felix García, 41, of Delano died on July 9, 2008 after loading grape boxes onto a company truck in Delano in extreme heat. (Photo courtesy of Raudel Felix García)

Now, Raudel Felix García is among those who are calling for the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration to establish the first federal standard that would protect workers from exposure to excessive heat.


“I don’t want any more families to go through the pain that my family went through,” he said.


RELATED STORY: U.S. Postal Service worker found dead in Woodland Hills amid Friday’s record-breaking heat


More than 100 labor, public health, environmental justice and environmental groups along with former occupational regulators and other individual petitioners submitted a petition to the federal agency calling for national protections for workers – both indoor and outdoor – who are at risk from extreme heat.


It marks the launch of a national campaign by the consumer rights advocacy group Public Citizen, the United Farm Workers Foundation and Farmworker Justice and others in an effort to raise awareness about the effects of climate change on workers’ health and safety.


“Preventing heat illness is urgently needed now more than ever,” Ellen Widess, a former Cal/OSHA chief and a board member of Farmworker Justice, said on the call. “Given climate change, rising heat, high-heat incidents and expanding areas of California and the nation which experience high heat, we have to do something.”


U.S. Rep. Judy Chu, D-Pasadena, said she plans to introduce legislation in Congress that would require the federal government to develop federal heat protection standards. These standards would likely require employers to provide workplaces with water, shade and rest breaks if needed to recover from the heat, similar to what California already requires.


The planned legislation would also direct employers to provide training for employees about risk factors that can lead to heat illness, Chu said.


“All workers should benefit from safe conditions whenever they work outside in the heat no matter where they are,” she said.


RELATED STORY: Federal investigators launch probe into Woodland Hills mail carrier’s death on 117-degree day


Locally, the issue of working in extreme heat gained attention recently after U.S. postal carrier Peggy Frank, 63, was found dead July 6 in her mail truck on a 117-degree day in Woodland Hills. Authorities, including OSHA, are probing whether heat was a factor.


Employers are obligated to protect employees from any hazardous condition, including potential heat stress, according to the U.S. Department of Labor.


In the case of the U.S. Postal Service, carriers are reminded daily to stay hydrated throughout their route, wear appropriate clothing, such as hats, and get into the shade whenever and as much as possible, officials said.


In 2005, after a series of farmworker deaths, California became the first state in the country to issue comprehensive heat standard protections for workers. Those regulations were strengthened a decade later and have likely saved lives, activists and experts say.


While there have been some tragic cases of heat-related deaths in the state since then, Chu said it’s probably related to enforcement of the state’s regulations.


“We feel it’s related to whether there are people being sent out to see whether employers are really doing their job and whether they are holding them accountable,” she said.


Chu added that she’s hopeful that the new legislation will tackle this problem.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

That sentiment was echoed by Widess, the former Cal/Osha chief, who said that even in a state like California, it’s important to increase enforcement capacity of regulatory agencies.


“More inspectors are needed to make sure employers are doing right by workers, taking every step needed, and OSHA is chronically understaffed nationally,” she said.

Brenda Gazzar

Brenda Gazzar is a multilingual multimedia reporter who has worked for a variety of news outlets in California and in the Middle East since 2000. She has covered a range of issues, including breaking news, immigration, law and order, race, religion and gender issues, politics, human interest stories and education. Besides the Los Angeles Daily News and its sister papers, her work has been published by Reuters, the Denver Post, Ms. Magazine, the Jerusalem Post, USA Today, the Christian Science Monitor, the Los Angeles Jewish Journal, The Cairo Times and others. News


Amid climate change and recent deaths, coalition demands worker protections from extreme heat


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* DWP crews work to restore power after weekend heat outages. (Courtesy LADWP)
By Brenda Gazzar | bgazzar@scng.com | Daily News

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 2:17 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 5:49 pm

Raudel Felix García of Fontana thought someone was playing a cruel joke on him when he was told a decade ago that his brother had died after working in the grape fields of Kern County.


Audon Felix García had arrived from Zacatecas, Mexico just days before to work in the fields as he had done every other summer, his brother said. But the 41-year-old died two days after starting work loading boxes on the company truck, he said, due to temperatures that reached 112 degrees that summer day and employer “negligence” to properly care for him.


“It was hard to believe that he was simply gone,” a highly emotional Raudel Felix García, who owns his own landscaping business, said Tuesday in a media teleconference. “I had seen Audon five days before his death. He was healthy and ready to start another harvesting season.”


Audon Felix García, 41, of Delano died on July 9, 2008 after loading grape boxes onto a company truck in Delano in extreme heat. (Photo courtesy of Raudel Felix García)

Now, Raudel Felix García is among those who are calling for the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration to establish the first federal standard that would protect workers from exposure to excessive heat.


“I don’t want any more families to go through the pain that my family went through,” he said.


RELATED STORY: U.S. Postal Service worker found dead in Woodland Hills amid Friday’s record-breaking heat


More than 100 labor, public health, environmental justice and environmental groups along with former occupational regulators and other individual petitioners submitted a petition to the federal agency calling for national protections for workers – both indoor and outdoor – who are at risk from extreme heat.


It marks the launch of a national campaign by the consumer rights advocacy group Public Citizen, the United Farm Workers Foundation and Farmworker Justice and others in an effort to raise awareness about the effects of climate change on workers’ health and safety.


“Preventing heat illness is urgently needed now more than ever,” Ellen Widess, a former Cal/OSHA chief and a board member of Farmworker Justice, said on the call. “Given climate change, rising heat, high-heat incidents and expanding areas of California and the nation which experience high heat, we have to do something.”


U.S. Rep. Judy Chu, D-Pasadena, said she plans to introduce legislation in Congress that would require the federal government to develop federal heat protection standards. These standards would likely require employers to provide workplaces with water, shade and rest breaks if needed to recover from the heat, similar to what California already requires.


The planned legislation would also direct employers to provide training for employees about risk factors that can lead to heat illness, Chu said.


“All workers should benefit from safe conditions whenever they work outside in the heat no matter where they are,” she said.


RELATED STORY: Federal investigators launch probe into Woodland Hills mail carrier’s death on 117-degree day


Locally, the issue of working in extreme heat gained attention recently after U.S. postal carrier Peggy Frank, 63, was found dead July 6 in her mail truck on a 117-degree day in Woodland Hills. Authorities, including OSHA, are probing whether heat was a factor.


Employers are obligated to protect employees from any hazardous condition, including potential heat stress, according to the U.S. Department of Labor.


In the case of the U.S. Postal Service, carriers are reminded daily to stay hydrated throughout their route, wear appropriate clothing, such as hats, and get into the shade whenever and as much as possible, officials said.


In 2005, after a series of farmworker deaths, California became the first state in the country to issue comprehensive heat standard protections for workers. Those regulations were strengthened a decade later and have likely saved lives, activists and experts say.


While there have been some tragic cases of heat-related deaths in the state since then, Chu said it’s probably related to enforcement of the state’s regulations.


“We feel it’s related to whether there are people being sent out to see whether employers are really doing their job and whether they are holding them accountable,” she said.


Chu added that she’s hopeful that the new legislation will tackle this problem.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

That sentiment was echoed by Widess, the former Cal/Osha chief, who said that even in a state like California, it’s important to increase enforcement capacity of regulatory agencies.


“More inspectors are needed to make sure employers are doing right by workers, taking every step needed, and OSHA is chronically understaffed nationally,” she said.

Dine 909: Sycamore Hills Plaza unveils two new eateries, with more to come


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Corky’s Kitchen & Bakery opened recently in Sycamore Hills Plaza at 2213 E. Base Line, Suite 200, Claremont. (Photo by John Plessel)
By John Plessel | jplessel@scng.com | San Bernardino Sun

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 11:10 am | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 11:10 am

Sycamore Hills Plaza continues filling out.


Two more eateries — Corky’s Kitchen & Bakery and WaBa Grill — opened recently in the center, which straddles the Claremont/Upland border and is anchored by CVS Pharmacy and Whole Foods Market 365.


  * The Bar and Noodle is open inside Whole Foods Market 365 at Sycamore Hills Plaza. (Photo by John Plessel)


  * WaBa Grill opened recently in Sycamore Hills Plaza at 2209 E. Base Line, Suite 600, Claremont. (Photo by John Plessel)

  * Sound
    The gallery will resume inseconds

  * Dog Haus Biergarten is set to open at Sycamore Hills Plaza. (Photo by John Plessel)


  * Corky’s Kitchen & Bakery opened recently in Sycamore Hills Plaza at 2213 E. Base Line, Suite 200, Claremont. (Photo by John Plessel)

* Show Caption
of

Expand


Corky’s and WaBa Grill join the previously opened Starbucks, MOD Pizza and SpireWorks Modern Döner, as well as Picnik and The Bar and Noodle, which are located inside Whole Foods.


Also slated to open at the center are Jersey Mike’s Subs, Dog Haus Biergarten, Wendy’s and Menchie’s Frozen Yogurt.


Sycamore Hills Plaza is on the north side of Base Line, just east of the 210 Freeway.


Dollar deals


McDonald’s fans, if you haven’t yet downloaded the chain’s mobile app, now is a good time to do so.


The app features weekly deals and the chain recently pushed some longer-term deep discounts that are worth taking advantage of.


Through the app, guests can purchase any sandwich — with the exception of a Signature Crafted sandwich or a double Quarter Pounder with Cheese — for just $1.


The deal is good once daily through Sept. 30.


Also available is a deal allowing the purchase of any size McCafé beverage for $1, which is valid once daily through Dec. 30.


Sorry, Starbucks.


Other long-term deals available through the app include:

  * $1 McDouble sandwich (valid once daily through Dec. 30)
  * $3 off a $10 purchase (valid once daily through Dec. 30)
  * 20-piece McNuggets for $4.99 (valid once daily through Dec. 30)
  * Buy one McCafé beverage (excluding drip and iced coffee), get one for one cent (valid once daily through Sept. 30)
  * Free hash browns with the purchase of any breakfast sandwich (valid once daily through Aug. 19)

These deals are in addition to the chain’s weekly deals, which in recent weeks have included a buy-one-get-one deal (either free or for $1) on Quarter Pounder with Cheese burgers.


The McDonald’s app, which also allows mobile ordering, is available for Android and iOS.


Free phone from Farmer Boys


Another app-related deal is being advertised by Farmer Boys.


The chain is offering a free Android smartphone with the purchase of two months of service for $100.


To begin the process, simply download the chain’s Very Important Farmer Loyalty Club app on Android or iOS or sign up by visiting www.farmerboys.com/vif.


The app allows guests to earn free food by scanning their receipts when they visit. New members also receive a $5 credit just for signing up.


Also, the chain is giving a bonus $8 credit for guests who visit three times in July and spend at least $5 each visit.


Details on the app and the free phone offer can be found at www.farmerboys.com/promotions.


Beer and bites for charity


Barons Market has announced its latest Backroom Beer Pairing, which is set for Wednesday, July 25.


The partner brewery for this month’s event is San Diego-based Thorn Brewing Company.


The event runs from 6 to 8 p.m.


The menu will consist of:

  * Rock the Pale Ale paired with Spicy Thai Chicken Lettuce Wraps
  * Hopster Pot paired with Summer Shrimp Ceviche
  * Barrio Lager paired with Sausage, Pepper & Onions Rolls
  * Relay IPA paired with Carrot Cheese Cake

Tickets are $15. Ticket sales from the markets’ Riverside County stores (Temecula, Wildomar and Murrieta) will benefit Feeding America Riverside | San Bernardino, while sales from its San Diego-area stores will benefit Feeding San Diego.


Visit the Beer Goggles blog (www.insidesocal.com/beer) for a link to purchase tickets.


Birthday burger deal


Ruby’s Diner is celebrating its namesake’s birthday with a special burger and fries deal.


From 11:30 a.m. to close on Wednesday, July 25, guests can purchase a birthday burger and fries for just $2.99.


The deal is available at select locations. The chain’s Inland Empire locations, at 4900 Seminole Drive, Cabazon, and 155 S. Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, are both participating.


Related Articles

  * Dine 909: Raising Cane’s opens at Ontario Mills, Roger’s Burgers lands in San Bernardino
  * Dine 909: MOD Pizza gives back with its new Isaac pizza
  * Dine 909: After five decades, The Deli finally adds a second location
  * Dine 909: Food, beer and wine events are ramping up now that summer’s here

From 11:30 a.m. to close on Wednesday, July 25, guests can purchase a birthday burger and fries for just $2.99.


The deal is available at select locations. The chain’s Inland Empire locations, at 4900 Seminole Drive, Cabazon, and 155 S. Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, are both participating.
